The Ascent USSR 1976 110 minutes

By the time Soviet director Larisa Shepitko was killed in a car accident at age 41, she had made only a handful of films. But she had already won a place in international film circles because one of those pictures, "The Ascent," was widely considered a masterpiece.

An uncompromising portrayal of war and betrayal that instantly placed Shepitko, a pupil of Alexander Dovzhenko, among the great filmmakers of the world. On the surface, The Ascent tells the tense and agonizing story of two Russians on the run in German-occupied Byelorussia. Underneath, it is a bold reversal of the heroics and stereotypes of Soviet officialdom, daringly expressed through explicit religious symbolism. The tough, earthy Rybak, daring and adept in blizzard and battle, crumples under threat of torture, while the scholarly Sotnikov, nervous and introspective, faces death with unsuspected reserves of courage. He discovers the ultimate identity in a spirituality that communism has failed to provide. Sheptiko’s last completed film before her tragic death. International Film Circuit

“A psychological adventure of almost mesmerizing tension and terror, leading to an overwhelming emotional and mystical crescendo of a climax.”
– Michael Wilmington, CHICAGO TRIBUNE

“Brilliantly ironic with the power and excitement of truths deeply believed.”
– Peter Keough, CHICAGO READER

After the film we'll go to a local restaurant for our group discussion.

Hope to see you there,
Tom
